plants.title: Neem
plants.description: Neem tree is India's oldest and most effective medicinal tree. It is called "village pharmacy" because everything on it - leaves, bark, seeds, oil - works as medicine. Neem purifies the blood, controls sugar levels, cures all skin diseases (pimples, rashes, itching, eczema), strengthens teeth and heals the mouth. It is anti-bacterial, anti-viral, anti-fungal, hence fights infections. It is also beneficial in fevers like malaria and dengue. It also keeps the liver and kidneys clean. It has been used since ancient times to purify blood, kill stomach worms and remove heat.
uses: Dental problems (toothache, bleeding gums, mouth ulcers)
plants.growingConditions: Full sunlight (6–8 hours daily), Well-drained sandy/loamy soil, pH 6.2–7.5, Tolerates drought & poor soil, Grows fast in hot climate, Can be grown in big pots or ground, Space 15–20 feet apart if in ground
plants.harvestingTips: Leaves: Pick young tender leaves anytime, best before flowering (Feb–May) Seeds: Collect ripe yellow fruits from tree in May–June, dry in shade Bark: Harvest only from mature trees (>5 years), peel gently in summer Never strip whole tree – take only 20–30%
plants.author: H. S. Puri

plants.title: Hibiscus
plants.description: Hibiscus sabdariffa, commonly known as Roselle, is an erect, mostly branched annual shrub that can grow up to 3.5 meters tall. Its stem has a reddish hue, and it possesses a deep-reaching taproot that helps in drought tolerance. The plant features large, deeply lobed leaves, which are typically green but can also exhibit reddish tinges, adding to its vivid tropical appeal. The leaves are alternately arranged, broad, and glossy.The flowers of Hibiscus sabdariffa are large, with a diameter of about 3 to 6 inches, and can be red, yellow, or white, often having a dark center containing short peduncles. The petals are bell-shaped, with some varieties bearing single or double rows of petals, and the blooms are short-lived, lasting only a day.
plants.growingConditions: Warm tropical or subtropical climate, well-drained loamy soil, full sun exposure, regular watering, moderate humidity, space for bushy growth.
plants.harvestingTips: Harvest the calyces (flower sepals) when they turn deep red and before they fully dry on the plant to retain maximum medicinal potency.
plants.author: E. Montalvo-González

plants.title: Ginger
plants.description: Ginger (Zingiber officinale) is a herbaceous perennial plant widely cultivated for its thick, aromatic, and branched underground rhizome used as a spice and medicine. The rhizome has a brown outer layer and pale yellow interior with a spicy, citrusy aroma. The plant grows pseudostems about 3 to 4 feet tall made from tightly wrapped leaf bases bearing narrow, lanceolate medium-green leaves arranged in two ranks. The flowers appear on a separate stalk and form dense, cone-shaped spikes with pale yellow petals and purplish edges. The rhizomes are juicy and fleshy when young, becoming more fibrous and pungent with maturity. Ginger thrives in humid, tropical, and subtropical climates, prefers well-drained fertile soil, and requires moderate water and partial shade to full sun. It is widely used in cooking.This herbal perennial is also known for its beautiful flowering spikes, making it a popular ornamental plant in subtropical gardens. Link: https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/09064710.2019.1606930
uses: 1)Fresh or dried rhizome used as spice or decoction
2)Ginger tea for relief from cold and cough
4)Oil and extracts used in massage for joint pain
plants.growingConditions: Prefers well-drained, fertile loamy soil, Partial shade to full sun exposure,Needs humid tropical or subtropical climate,Requires loose, rich soil with organic matter
plants.harvestingTips: Harvest rhizomes 8-10 months after planting when leaves turn yellow and dry; gentle digging recommended to avoid damage
plants.author: Keshab Raj Paudel

plants.title: Cinnamon
plants.description: Cinnamon (Cinnamomum verum), also known as Ceylon cinnamon, is a small evergreen tree or bushy shrub belonging to the laurel family (Lauraceae). It typically grows 8 to 15 meters tall in the wild but as a cultivated plant is often kept shorter by coppicing. The tree has thick, smooth bark from which the spice is derived by peeling the dried inner bark.Overall, cinnamon is a fragrant, versatile medicinal and culinary herb with deep cultural and economic importance, especially in South Asia and Sri Lanka
uses: 3( anti-inflammatory for arthritis and joint pain
plants.growingConditions: Tropical climate, warm temperature, well-drained soil, slightly acidic to neutral pH (6.0-7.0), partial to full sunlight, high humidity, protection from strong wind, moderate fertilizer, organic-rich soil.
plants.harvestingTips: Harvest the cinnamon bark when the tree is 2-3 years old; the bark is peeled off from branches and dried properly. The best quality bark peels easily into thin curls.
plants.author: P. Kawatra

plants.title: Ashwagandha
plants.description: Ashwagandha (Withania somnifera) contains a rich variety of chemical compounds responsible for its medicinal properties. The primary bioactive constituents are withanolides, which are steroidal lactones, including compounds like withaferin A, withanolide A, and withanolide D. These compounds structurally resemble the ginsenosides found in Panax ginseng, earning Ashwagandha the nickname "Indian ginseng"The mineral content includes essential elements like copper, iron, zinc, magnesium, manganese, cobalt, and nickel, which also support its health benefits .This detailed phytochemical content explains its wide use in traditional Indian medicine and growing scientific validation.
uses: 1)Root powder or extract used as a general tonic
2(Leaf paste applied for inflammation and skin infections
4)Bark decoction for asthma and bed sores
4)Herbal teas, syrups, and tablets prepared from roots and extracts
plants.growingConditions: Full sun (at least 6 hours daily)Warm climate,Sandy loam soil, Well-drained soil, Neutral to slightly alkaline pH (7.5–8.0)Avoid clay-heavy or waterlogged soil, Add compost or organic manure, Plant seeds half an inch deep, Space plants 18–24 inches apart ,Use deep containers of at least 10-12 inches if potted
plants.harvestingTips: Harvest roots after 5–6 months of growth, Best harvested during late autumn or early winter, Dig carefully to avoid damaging roots, Wash roots thoroughly before drying or processing
plants.author: Mir et al.

plants.title: Tulsi
plants.description: Tulsi is known as “Mother Tulsi” and “Holy Basil” in India. It is a small bush which grows 30-60 cm tall, has fragrant leaves and small purple or pink flowers. It is planted in the courtyard of every house because it is considered an antidote to sin and good for health.
uses: Fresh 4–5 leaves chewed daily on empty stomach
Tulsi kadha (decoction) for cold, cough & fever
Tulsi tea for stress relief and immunity
Tulsi ark (distilled extract) – 10-15 drops in water
Tulsi powder with honey for respiratory problems
Tulsi juice for skin problems and acne
Tulsi smoke (dhoop) for purifying air and mosquito repellent
plants.growingConditions: Full sunlight (6–8 hours daily) Well-drained loamy or sandy-loam soil pH 6–7.5 Can be grown in pots, balconies, terrace Seeds or stem cuttings for propagation Perennial plant (lives 2–3 years easily)
plants.harvestingTips: Harvest leaves in the morning after dew dries Pluck top 3–4 leaves with stem to encourage bushy growth Never remove more than 30% of plant at once Regular plucking increases lifespan and yield
plants.author: Carl Linnaeus

plants.title: Turmeric
plants.description: Turmeric is a perennial herb that belongs to the ginger family. Its root (rhizome) is dried to form the yellow-orange powder we call turmeric. In Ayurveda, it's called "Haridra" and has been used for over 4,000 years.
uses: Drinking golden milk daily to boost immunity
Applying fresh turmeric paste on cuts, burns, or wounds for quick healing
Taking turmeric with warm milk during sprains, injuries, or body pain
Using turmeric face pack (with curd, besan, or milk) for acne, pigmentation, and glowing skin
Consuming turmeric regularly for joint pain and arthritis relief
plants.growingConditions: Full sun (6–8 hours daily) Well-drained loamy or red soil pH 5.5–7.5 Can grow in big pots or ground Planting time: June–July (rainy season) Rhizomes (fingers)
plants.harvestingTips: 8–10 months after planting (when leaves turn yellow and dry) Carefully dig out rhizomes Keep some fingers for next season planting Boil freshly dug rhizomes for 30–45 min, dry in sun 10–15 days, then polish and store
plants.author: Linnaeus (L.)

plants.title: Aloe Vera
plants.description: Aloe Vera is a plant with thick, resinous leaves that grows in dry areas. Its gel is cool, viscous and transparent, which provides quick relief when applied to the skin. In Ayurveda, it is called "Ghritkumari" or "Kumari" and it calms Pitta Dosha. It is very beneficial in burning sensation, minor wounds, sunburn, acne, hair fall, constipation, sugar control, and boosting immunity. When taken internally, it cleanses the stomach, strengthens the liver, and purifies the blood. When applied externally, it makes the skin glow, reduces wrinkles, and prevents infections.
uses: Gel applied on minor cuts and abrasions.
Gel applied on small burns to reduce pain and speed healing.
Gel used as natural moisturizer for dry skin.
Processed Aloe vera gel or creams for acne, eczema support (topical).
plants.growingConditions: Full sunlight (6-8 hours), Well-draining sandy soil, Pots with drainage holes, Can grow in balcony or terrace, Tolerates neglect, Drought resistant, Protect from heavy rain and waterlogging
plants.harvestingTips: Cut outer mature leaves from base with sharp knife Choose thick, lower leaves (at least 1 year old) Leave at least 8-10 leaves on plant for its health Harvest in morning for maximum gel After cutting, let yellow sap (aloin) drain for 10-15 min before using gel
plants.author: Burman
